page.title: 04ECOLOGY. TREES WILLEY.
page.content: Willey is a saxon word meaning willow wood but today there are few willows left in the area. These are white willows. The most common trees are holly,elder, hazel, and hawthorn which were originally planted for hedging but are now growing wild as well.The vallet woods are planted with Sitka spruce, European larch & Tsuga but there are other trees such as oak, beech, ash, birch, sycamore and elm although the latter are all now dead from dutch elm disease. The area also has a number of wild cherry trees and at Cwm Crave a fine lime tree grows. Of the walnut trees once in the area, few now remain. The 3rd oldest oak tree in Hereford is situated at Willey Hall and is regularly inspected by county officials.
